Hayes To Appear
At Next Assembly
Arthur Garfield Hayes, militant attorney and defender of Labor's right,
will speak at the next assembly,
Thursday, in Latrobe Hall.
Mr. Hayes, who has made three
previous talks at the Hopkins, was
poplarly received, being accorded loud
ovations by the audiences. At his
first appearance, the New York attorney spoke on the Scopes Trial.
Conditions in Kentucky were described to the Hopkins student body
by Mr. Hayes. Last year the speaker
addressed an assembly on the Reichstag fire, having just returned from

Miss Frieda Thies, head librarian
of the reading room, has been chosen
as sponsor of the Johns Hopkins University Library Dance to be held in
Levering Hall tonight.
The dance features the music of the
"Grenadiers", popular Baltimore or-

A novel features of the dance is
that tables will be available for playing cards.
This is the first social event ever
given by the group and it is hoped
that a series of similar affairs under
the auspices of the Library will fol-

By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
Embarking on its second approach
to the problem of stabilizing peace
in the world, the Association of College Editors, in collaboration with
the Literary Digest, will conduct a
nation-wide peace poll on January 6,
1935. The poll is expected to reach
more than 300,000 undergraduates in
150,000 American colleges and universities, in which group the Johns
Hopkins has been included.

Due to another engagement, Dr.
Florence E. Bamberger, professor of
education at the Hopkins, will be unable to give her address on the
"Stage in Education," the second lecture of a series offered by the Playshop, next Tuesday.
However, the lecture will be given
on Monday, December 10, at 8:30 p.
m. in the Playshop.
Following the lecture, a one-act

Two Plans Offered
$11 Proposal Provided For
Reduced 1935 Hullabaloo
And Modified June Week
By a vote of 26 to 4, the Senior
Class decided to retain its $15 class
dues, rejecting the proposed change
to $11, at an assembly held the last
Tuesday before the Thanksgiving
holidays.
The outcome of the vote means
that seniors will have a Hullabaloo
of high standard with photographs
of two students on each page and an
elaborate June Week. The proposed
$11 called for a reduced Hullabaloo
with four pictures to a page and a
modified June Week.
Clark, McConnell Give Budgets
A. E. Clark, Jr., business manager
of the Hullabaloo, and William McConnell, chairman of the June Week
Committee, each presented a separate budget to the members of the
class and explained what curtailment
a $11 fee would necessitate. Following these reports, a lengthy discussion was held and a vote was finally
taken.
Although only a small percentage
of the class attended the meeting and
voted, Roland Merson, president of
the Senior Class, announced that he
would interpret the results of the
ballot as indicative of the sentiment
of the entire class. He added that
plans for the Hullabaloo and June
Week would proceed without further
delay.
A clause in the class constitution
which provides a check for Merson
on all Senior Class activities was approved by the assembly.

and Blue Jay, said:
"As a whole, in rereading the batch!
of papers, I was struck by the wealth
of news presented therein. I feel that
many of the best articles are stuck
away on the third or fourth pages, or
under poor heads, and are never read
as a consequence.
"I was impressed by the small
journalistic mistakes which tend to
throw an otherwise good article into
the high school class. Small, choppy
leads, poorly written leads, extraneous sentences thrown in here and
there, tend to ruin a story and signify an excessive haste in publication.
Corrections in this sort of thing
would be nothing more than the devotion of few minutes' indulgence.
"There would seem to be an almost
complete lack of editorial controversy, or editorial issues. The main
ones of the past month were those
aroused by the Hearst to-do and the
small rumpus over the dedication of
the gymnasium, which was certainly
a mole-hill."
Editor Criticises
Blumberg, the NEWS-LETTER editor,
agreed that many important stories
which are buried in the third and
fourth pages should be on page one
and that the writing of many stories
is poor. He said, further:
"There has been a decided improvement in the NEWS-LETTER and I feel
that this year's paper is still showing
the upward trend which has been
shown by those edited in the past
two years by Norman Heaney and
Hyman Levin. The makeup of the
paper, too, has improved tremendous-

been "in tobacco" for years—growing tobacco
and curing it—buying it and selling it—until
they know tobacco from A to Izzard.
Now folks who have been in tobacco all
their lives, folks who grow it, know there is
no substitute for mild ripe tobacco.
And down in the South where they grow tobacco
and where they ought to know something about it—in
most _places Chesterfield is the largest-selling cigarette.

Arthur Garfield Hayes, militant attorney and defender of Labor's right,
will speak at the next assembly,
Thursday, in Latrobe Hall.

previous talks at the Hopkins, was
poplarly received, being accorded loud
ovations by the audiences. At his
first appearance, the New York attorney spoke on the Scopes Trial.

more than 300,000 undergraduates in
150,000 American colleges and universities, in which group the Johns

Due to another engagement, Dr.
Florence E. Bamberger, professor of
education at the Hopkins, will be unable to give her address on the
"Stage in Education," the second lecture of a series offered by the Playshop, next Tuesday.
However, the lecture will be given
on Monday, December 10, at 8:30 p.
m. in the Playshop.
Following the lecture, a one-act

Two Plans Offered
$11 Proposal Provided For
Reduced 1935 Hullabaloo
And Modified June Week
By a vote of 26 to 4, the Senior
Class decided to retain its $15 class
dues, rejecting the proposed change
to $11, at an assembly held the last
Tuesday before the Thanksgiving
holidays.
The outcome of the vote means
that seniors will have a Hullabaloo
of high standard with photographs
of two students on each page and an
elaborate June Week. The proposed
$11 called for a reduced Hullabaloo
with four pictures to a page and a
modified June Week.
Clark, McConnell Give Budgets
A. E. Clark, Jr., business manager
of the Hullabaloo, and William McConnell, chairman of the June Week
Committee, each presented a separate budget to the members of the
class and explained what curtailment
a $11 fee would necessitate. Following these reports, a lengthy discussion was held and a vote was finally
taken.
Although only a small percentage
of the class attended the meeting and
voted, Roland Merson, president of
the Senior Class, announced that he
would interpret the results of the
ballot as indicative of the sentiment
of the entire class. He added that
plans for the Hullabaloo and June
Week would proceed without further
delay.
A clause in the class constitution
which provides a check for Merson
on all Senior Class activities was approved by the assembly.

[Continued from Page 1, Column 6]
and Blue Jay, said:
"As a whole, in rereading the batch!
of papers, I was struck by the wealth
of news presented therein. I feel that
many of the best articles are stuck
away on the third or fourth pages, or
under poor heads, and are never read
as a consequence.
"I was impressed by the small
journalistic mistakes which tend to
throw an otherwise good article into
the high school class. Small, choppy
leads, poorly written leads, extraneous sentences thrown in here and
there, tend to ruin a story and signify an excessive haste in publication.
Corrections in this sort of thing
would be nothing more than the devotion of few minutes' indulgence.
"There would seem to be an almost
complete lack of editorial controversy, or editorial issues. The main
ones of the past month were those
aroused by the Hearst to-do and the
small rumpus over the dedication of
the gymnasium, which was certainly
a mole-hill."
Editor Criticises
Blumberg, the NEWS-LETTER editor,
agreed that many important stories
which are buried in the third and
fourth pages should be on page one
and that the writing of many stories
is poor. He said, further:
"There has been a decided improvement in the NEWS-LETTER and I feel
that this year's paper is still showing
the upward trend which has been
shown by those edited in the past
two years by Norman Heaney and
Hyman Levin. The makeup of the
paper, too, has improved tremendous-

no substitute for mild ripe tobacco.

and where they ought to know something about it—in
most _places Chesterfield is the largest-selling cigarette.
